candidates.definition: Chemically inert gaseous elements that rarely react with other substances under normal conditions

positive_examples: The helium balloon floated away because helium is lighter than air
Neon signs glow brightly when electricity passes through the gas
Argon is used to fill light bulbs to prevent the filament from oxidizing
Krypton gas is used in high-performance camera flash bulbs
Xenon headlights provide brighter illumination than halogen bulbs
Radon gas can accumulate in basements and pose health risks
negative_examples: Oxygen is essential for combustion and breathing
Nitrogen makes up most of the atmosphere but forms many compounds
Hydrogen gas is highly reactive and explosive
Chlorine gas is toxic and highly reactive with metals
Carbon dioxide dissolves in water to form carbonic acid
Ammonia gas readily dissolves in water forming a basic solution
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: ReactiveGases, Metals, Nonmetals, Halogens

candidates.definition: highly reactive metallic elements in Group 1 of the periodic table that form alkaline solutions when combined with water

positive_examples: The sodium in salt water makes it highly conductive to electricity.
Lithium batteries are prized for their light weight and high energy density.
Potassium is essential for proper muscle and nerve function in the human body.
The laboratory stored rubidium under oil to prevent violent reactions with air.
Cesium atomic clocks are used as the international standard for measuring time.
Francium is so radioactive that it decays almost immediately after formation.
negative_examples: Magnesium burns with a bright white flame when ignited in air.
Aluminum foil is commonly used for wrapping food and cooking.
Iron rusts when exposed to oxygen and moisture over time.
Copper wires conduct electricity efficiently in electrical systems.
Gold maintains its lustrous appearance without tarnishing over centuries.
The zinc coating protects the steel from corrosion in galvanized metal.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: AlkalineEarthMetals, TransitionMetals, NobleGases, Halogens, Metalloids

candidates.definition: Group 2 metallic elements with two valence electrons that form divalent cations and basic oxides

positive_examples: The calcium in milk helps strengthen bones and teeth.
Magnesium supplements can help reduce muscle cramps after exercise.
Barium sulfate is used as a contrast agent in medical X-rays.
The brilliant white flame indicates the presence of magnesium in the firework.
Strontium gives red fireworks their distinctive crimson color.
Radium was once used to make glow-in-the-dark watch dials before its dangers were known.
negative_examples: Sodium chloride dissolves easily in water to form table salt.
The aluminum foil wrapped around the leftover pizza.
Iron oxide causes the reddish-brown rust on old cars.
Copper pipes are commonly used in residential plumbing systems.
The gold necklace gleamed in the jewelry store window.
Carbon dioxide emissions contribute to climate change.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: AlkaliMetals, TransitionMetals, NobleGases, Halogens

candidates.definition: Group 17 elements that are highly reactive nonmetals forming salts with metals

positive_examples: The swimming pool was treated with chlorine to kill bacteria
Fluoride toothpaste helps prevent tooth decay
Bromine is extracted from seawater for industrial use
Iodine solution was applied to disinfect the wound
Table salt contains sodium and chlorine atoms
Fluorine compounds are used in refrigeration systems
negative_examples: Oxygen gas is essential for breathing
Nitrogen makes up most of the atmosphere
Hydrogen is the lightest element
Sulfur forms yellow crystals
Carbon forms the basis of organic compounds
Phosphorus glows in the dark
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: NobleGases, AlkaliMetals, TransitionMetals, Metalloids

candidates.definition: rare earth metallic elements with atomic numbers 57-71, typically soft and reactive with similar chemical properties

positive_examples: The neodymium magnets in the hard drive are incredibly strong
Cerium oxide is used as a polishing compound for glass
The europium in the phosphor gives the screen its red color
Samarium-cobalt magnets work well at high temperatures
Gadolinium contrast agents help improve MRI image quality
Terbium is essential for the green phosphors in fluorescent lights
negative_examples: Scandium and yttrium are also rare earth elements but not lanthanides
Actinium is radioactive but belongs to the actinide series instead
Hafnium has similar properties but is a transition metal
Thorium is found in rare earth ores but is an actinide
Zirconium often occurs with rare earths but is not a lanthanide
Titanium dioxide is used in similar applications but is not a rare earth
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: Actinides, TransitionMetals, AlkaliMetals, NobleGases, Halogens

candidates.definition: Radioactive metallic elements with atomic numbers 89-103, including uranium and transuranics

positive_examples: The uranium fuel rods were carefully handled due to their radioactive properties
Plutonium-239 is used in nuclear weapons and reactor fuel
Thorium reactors offer a safer alternative to conventional nuclear power
Americium-241 is commonly found in household smoke detectors
The neptunium isotope was produced artificially in the particle accelerator
Curium samples require special containment due to their intense radioactivity
negative_examples: The radon gas accumulated in the basement over time
Cesium-137 contamination spread after the nuclear accident
The technetium isotope is widely used in medical imaging
Polonium poisoning was suspected in the assassination case
Radium paint made the watch dials glow in the dark
The tritium exit signs provided emergency lighting
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: Lanthanides, TransitionMetals, AlkaliMetals, NobleGases, Halogens

candidates.definition: Metallic elements with partially filled d-orbitals that exhibit variable oxidation states and form colored compounds.

positive_examples: The steel beam contains iron and chromium for strength and corrosion resistance.
Copper wiring conducts electricity efficiently throughout the building.
The catalyst uses platinum to speed up the chemical reaction.
Titanium implants are biocompatible and lightweight for medical use.
Nickel plating gives the surface a shiny, protective coating.
Manganese is added to steel to improve its hardness and durability.
negative_examples: Aluminum foil wraps the sandwich to keep it fresh.
The sodium chloride dissolved completely in water.
Carbon forms the backbone of all organic molecules.
Helium gas filled the birthday balloons.
Silicon chips power modern electronic devices.
Sulfur crystals formed yellow deposits near the volcano.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: AlkaliMetals, NobleGases, Halogens, AlkalineEarthMetals

candidates.definition: Metallic elements located between transition metals and metalloids on the periodic table, typically soft and having lower melting points

positive_examples: The aluminum foil crinkled as she wrapped the leftover pizza
Lead pipes in old houses can contaminate drinking water
Tin cans are commonly used for food storage and preservation
Bismuth crystals form beautiful rainbow-colored geometric patterns
Gallium metal melts when held in your hand due to body heat
Indium is used in touchscreen displays for its conductive properties
negative_examples: Iron rusts when exposed to moisture and oxygen over time
Copper wire conducts electricity efficiently in electrical systems
Silicon chips power modern computers and electronic devices
Gold jewelry maintains its shine without tarnishing or corroding
Carbon forms the backbone of all organic molecules
Chlorine gas was used as a chemical weapon in World War I
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: TransitionMetals, AlkaliMetals, NobleGases, Halogens, Metalloids

candidates.definition: Elements with properties intermediate between metals and nonmetals, often used as semiconductors

positive_examples: Silicon wafers are essential components in computer chips and solar panels
Arsenic contamination in groundwater poses serious health risks to communities
Germanium's semiconductor properties make it valuable for fiber optic systems
Boron compounds are used in glass manufacturing and as flame retardants
Antimony alloys improve the hardness of lead in car batteries
Tellurium gives rubber its distinctive properties when used as an additive
negative_examples: Iron ore contains high concentrations of metallic elements
Oxygen makes up about 21% of Earth's atmosphere
Gold jewelry retains its luster due to the metal's resistance to tarnishing
Chlorine gas was used as a chemical weapon in World War I
Carbon forms the backbone of all organic molecules
Helium balloons float because the gas is lighter than air
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: Metals, Nonmetals, NobleGases, Halogens

candidates.definition: Chemical elements that typically lack metallic properties like conductivity and luster, often forming covalent bonds and existing as gases or brittle solids.

positive_examples: The nitrogen in the air we breathe makes up most of our atmosphere.
Oxygen is essential for combustion and cellular respiration.
Carbon forms the backbone of all organic molecules in living things.
Phosphorus is a key component in DNA and energy storage molecules.
Sulfur gives rotten eggs their distinctive smell when it forms hydrogen sulfide.
Selenium is used in photocells because its conductivity changes with light.
negative_examples: Iron rusts when exposed to moisture and oxygen over time.
The copper wiring conducts electricity throughout the building efficiently.
Gold maintains its lustrous appearance even after centuries of exposure.
Aluminum foil reflects heat and light due to its metallic surface.
The steel beam provides structural support due to its strength.
Silver jewelry tarnishes when exposed to sulfur compounds in air.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: Metals, Metalloids, AlkaliMetals, TransitionMetals
